evidence_clusters.description: Evidence and commentary proposing (or criticizing) hormesis/nanoparticle mechanisms as a partial explanation for some homeopathic preparations, focusing on low-dose biological responses and conceptual fit.

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive about whether a hormesis/nanoparticle debate literature exists; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: If homeopathy works via an unknown remedy-specific mechanism (e.g., water memory), a distinct hormesis/nanoparticle debate is not especially expected; below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If no specific effect exists, some debate literature may still exist but sustained supportive low-dose mechanistic claims are less expected overall; below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 does not specifically predict hormesis/nanoparticle mechanistic debate; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 (ritual/context) does not specifically predict a low-dose mechanism debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: H5 directly predicts that low-dose/hormetic/nanoparticle mechanisms should be discussed and supported by some experimental models; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under K1, mechanistic pluralism is encouraged; even if H1 is true, hormesis/nanoparticle frameworks are viewed as supportive adjuncts; slightly above base. (P(E|H1)>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K1 still expects some hormesis discussion but less than if H5 were true; below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 is not specifically a hormesis hypothesis; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 does not specifically predict hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: K1 expects strong visibility of hormesis/nanoparticle evidence if H5 is true; well above base. (P(E|H5)>>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: K2 expects hormesis/nanoparticle debate to be a post-hoc rationalization rather than a core prediction of H1; below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K2 expects a mix of speculative supportive claims and critical rebuttals to exist; slightly above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: H3 is non-predictive about hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 is non-predictive about hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: Even under K2, if H5 were true some hormesis/nanoparticle evidence/debate is expected; above base but not extreme due to skepticism about applicability to ultra-dilutions. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

scenario_config.proposition: Does homeopathy work better than placebo for treating medical conditions?

paradigms.name: Scientific Consensus
paradigms.description: Mainstream scientific and medical consensus based on RCTs, meta-analyses, and mechanistic understanding.
paradigms.ontology: Material, measurable biological and chemical processes
paradigms.epistemology: Empirical observation, RCTs, systematic reviews, falsification

paradigms.name: Integrative Medicine Advocate
paradigms.description: Perspective that values holistic approaches and considers patient-reported outcomes alongside RCTs.
paradigms.epistemology: Clinical experience, patient narratives, holistic assessment
paradigms.axiology: Patient autonomy, whole-person care, therapeutic relationship

paradigms.name: Skeptical Empiricist
paradigms.description: Strictly materialist view that demands mechanistic explanations and rejects implausible claims.
paradigms.ontology: Physical matter and measurable forces only
paradigms.epistemology: Mechanism-first, extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence
paradigms.axiology: Scientific rigor, preventing harm from ineffective treatments

hypotheses.name: OTHER - Unforeseen explanation
hypotheses.description: Some unknown mechanism not captured by the other hypotheses explains homeopathy's observed effects (or lack thereof).

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Homeopathy has specific therapeutic effects
hypotheses.description: Homeopathic remedies have specific therapeutic effects beyond placebo through an as-yet-unknown mechanism (e.g., water memory, quantum effects, nanoparticles).

hypotheses.name: FALSE - No effect beyond placebo
hypotheses.description: Homeopathic remedies have no specific therapeutic effect beyond placebo. Any perceived benefits are due to placebo effect, regression to mean, natural recovery, or concurrent conventional treatment.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Works for some conditions only
hypotheses.description: Homeopathy has specific effects for certain conditions (e.g., allergies, anxiety) but not others. The mechanism may be placebo-enhanced or condition-specific.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Therapeutic ritual effect
hypotheses.description: Homeopathy's effects come not from the remedies themselves but from the extended consultation, individualized attention, and therapeutic relationship - a real but non-specific effect.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Low-dose hormesis
hypotheses.description: Some homeopathic preparations at lower dilutions (not ultra-diluted) may have hormetic effects - beneficial responses to low-dose stressors - but this doesn't apply to standard ultra-diluted preparations.

items.description: A sensitivity analysis of Shang et al.'s 2005 meta-analysis in J Clin Epidemiology found that when all high-quality homeopathy trials were included, homeopathy showed a significant effect beyond placebo (OR=0.76; 95% CI: 0.59–0.99; p=0.039). However, results were highly heterogeneous (I2=62.2%) and conclusions varied substantially with trial selection.
items.citation_apa: Lüdtke, R., & Rutten, A. L. B. (2008). The conclusions on the effectiveness of homeopathy highly depend on the set of analyzed trials. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology, 61(12), 1197–1204. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclinepi.2008.06.015

items.description: Shang et al.'s Lancet meta-analysis (2005) comparing 110 placebo-controlled homeopathy trials with 110 conventional medicine trials found that in the eight highest-quality homeopathy trials the odds ratio was 0.88 (95% CI: 0.65–1.19), indicating no specific effect beyond placebo.
items.citation_apa: Shang, A., Huwiler-Müntener, K., Nartey, L., et al. (2005). Are the clinical effects of homeopathy placebo effects? Comparative study of placebo-controlled trials of homeopathy and allopathy. The Lancet, 366(9487), 726–732. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67177-2

items.description: Mathie et al. (2014) conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of 32 RCTs of individualised homeopathic treatment, finding a pooled odds ratio of 1.53 (p<0.001) across 22 trials, and in three trials rated as reliable an OR of 1.98 (p=0.013), suggesting effects distinguishable from placebo.
items.citation_apa: Mathie, R. T., Lloyd, S. M., Legg, L. A., Clausen, J., Moss, S., Davidson, J. R. T., & Ford, I. (2014). Randomised placebo-controlled trials of individualised homeopathic treatment: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Systematic Reviews, 3, 142. https://doi.org/10.1186/2046-4053-3-142

items.description: The Australian NHMRC review (2015) assessed 225 studies over 68 conditions and concluded there is no good-quality evidence that homeopathy is more effective than placebo, warning that using homeopathy in place of evidence-based treatments may endanger health.
items.citation_apa: Australian Broadcasting Corporation. (2015, March 11). Homeopathy no more effective than placebos, a study by the National Health and Medical Research Council finds. ABC News. https://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-11/homeopathy-no-more-effective-than-placebos-major-study-says/6302722

items.description: A 2019 Science Feedback review concluded that large-scale reviews of homeopathy clinical trials have not found effects beyond placebo, and that the purported mechanisms are implausible given established biology, chemistry, and physics.
items.citation_apa: Science Feedback. (2019, June 26). Despite claims of curative effects, homeopathy has been shown to lack clinical efficacy and plausibility. Science Feedback. https://science.feedback.org/review/despite-claims-of-curative-effects-homeopathy-has-been-shown-to-lack-clinical-efficacy-and-plausibility/

items.description: In the book Trick or Treatment? (2008), Singh and Ernst review alternative medicine modalities and conclude that homeopathy’s efficacy is attributable to placebo effects and that scientific evidence for specific effects is lacking.
items.citation_apa: Singh, S., & Ernst, E. (2008). Trick or Treatment? Alternative Medicine on Trial. Bantam Press.

items.description: News-Medical (2019) reports NHS leaders warning that homeopathy is at best placebo, misuse of scarce funds, and lacking proof of effects beyond placebo for any condition.
items.citation_apa: News-Medical.net. (2019, October 29). Homeopathy quackery: NHS leaders urge caution. News-Medical.net. https://www.news-medical.net/news/20191029/Homeopathy-quackery-NHS-leaders-urge-caution.aspx

items.description: EASAC’s 2017 statement “Homeopathy: harmful or helpful?” asserts there is no robust, reproducible evidence that homeopathic products are effective for any disease and that any perceived benefit is due to placebo or biases.
items.citation_apa: European Academies’ Science Advisory Council. (2017, September 20). Homeopathy: harmful or helpful? European scientists recommend an evidence-based approach. EASAC. https://easac.eu/media-room/press-releases/details/homeopathy-harmful-or-helpful-european-scientists-recommend-an-evidence-based-approach

items.description: Meta-analysis of 89 placebo-controlled homeopathy trials by Linde et al. (1997) reported combined odds ratio 2.45 (95% CI 2.05–2.93) favoring homeopathy over placebo; for 26 good-quality studies OR 1.66 (95% CI 1.33–2.08), and bias-corrected OR 1.78 (95% CI 1.03–3.10), concluding that effects cannot be attributed solely to placebo.
items.citation_apa: Linde, K., Clausius, N., Ramirez, G., Melchart, D., Eitel, F., Hedges, L. V., & Jonas, W. B. (1997). Are the clinical effects of homeopathy placebo effects? A meta-analysis of placebo-controlled trials. The Lancet, 350(9081), 834–843. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(97)02293-9

items.description: Meta-analysis by Shang et al. (2005) of 110 homeopathy and 110 conventional medicine trials found that in high-quality large trials the odds ratio was 0.88 (95% CI 0.65–1.19) for homeopathy versus 0.58 (95% CI 0.39–0.85) for conventional medicine, concluding no specific effect beyond placebo for homeopathy.
items.citation_apa: Shang, A., Huwiler-Müntener, K., Nartey, L., Jüni, P., Dörig, S., Sterne, J. A., Pewsner, D., & Egger, M. (2005). Are the clinical effects of homoeopathy placebo effects? Comparative study of placebo-controlled trials of homoeopathy and allopathy. The Lancet, 366(9487), 726–732. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67177-2

items.description: Cochrane review on homeopathy for irritable bowel syndrome (Peckham et al., 2019) concluded that evidence for effectiveness and safety of homeopathy versus placebo is uncertain due to low-quality and inadequately powered RCTs, precluding firm conclusions.
items.citation_apa: Peckham, E. J., Cooper, K., Roberts, E. R., Agrawal, A., Brabyn, S., & Tew, G. (2019). Homeopathy for treatment of irritable bowel syndrome. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 9, CD009710. https://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD009710.pub3

items.description: Systematic review by Ernst & Pittler (1998) of eight placebo-controlled trials of homeopathic Arnica montana found that on balance there is no evidence that Arnica is more efficacious than placebo, with most trials showing severe methodological flaws.
items.citation_apa: Ernst, E., & Pittler, M. H. (1998). Efficacy of homeopathic Arnica: A systematic review of placebo-controlled clinical trials. Archives of Surgery, 133(11), 1187–1190. https://doi.org/10.1001/archsurg.133.11.1187

items.description: Cochrane review on homeopathic medicinal products for preventing and treating acute respiratory tract infections in children (Hawke et al., 2022) found no consistent benefit compared to placebo; evidence was judged low to very low certainty.
items.citation_apa: Hawke, K., King, D., van Driel, M. L., & McGuire, T. M. (2022). Homeopathic medicinal products for preventing and treating acute respiratory tract infections in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 12, CD005974. https://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD005974.pub6

items.description: Systematic review of 18 veterinary RCTs of homeopathy (Mathie & Clausen, 2014) identified two reliable, free-from-interest trials: homeopathic Coli showed prophylactic effect on porcine diarrhoea (OR 3.89; 95% CI 1.19–12.68; P=0.02), while individualised homeopathic treatment did not improve bovine mastitis (SMD -0.31; 95% CI -0.97–0.34; P=0.35).
items.citation_apa: Mathie, R. T., Clausen, J., Moss, S., Davidson, J. R. T., & Ford, I. (2014). Veterinary homeopathy: systematic review of medical conditions studied by randomised placebo-controlled trials. Veterinary Record, 175(15), 373–381. https://doi.org/10.1136/vr.101767

items.description: Systematic review of 25 randomized placebo-controlled trials of homeopathy in psychiatric conditions (Davidson et al., 2011) found efficacy for functional somatic syndromes (fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue) but not for anxiety or stress, with mixed effects for other disorders.
items.source_name: Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE)
items.citation_apa: Davidson, J. R. T., Crawford, C., Ives, J. A., & Jonas, W. B. (2011). Homeopathic treatments in psychiatry: a systematic review of randomized placebo-controlled studies. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry, 72(6), 795–805.

items.description: Systematic review by Antonelli & Donelli (2019) concluded that homeopathy efficacy is comparable to placebo, and that placebo effects (treatment context, physician-patient relationship) likely underlie observed benefits, reinterpreting homeopathy as a placebo treatment.
items.source_name: Health & Social Care in the Community
items.citation_apa: Antonelli, M., & Donelli, D. (2019). Reinterpreting homoeopathy in the light of placebo effects to manage patients who seek homoeopathic care: A systematic review. Health & Social Care in the Community, 27(4), 824–847. https://doi.org/10.1111/hsc.12681

items.description: Meta-analysis of 110 placebo-controlled homeopathy trials and 110 matched conventional medicine trials found that when restricted to the eight highest-quality homeopathy trials, the pooled odds ratio was 0.88 (95% CI 0.65–1.19), indicating no effect beyond placebo, whereas conventional interventions showed a stronger effect (OR=0.58; 95% CI 0.39–0.85).
items.citation_apa: Shang, A., Huwiler-Müntener, K., Nartey, L., Jüni, P., Dörig, S., Sterne, J. A. C., Pewsner, D., & Egger, M. (2005). Are the clinical effects of homœopathy placebo effects? Comparative study of placebo-controlled trials of homœopathy and allopathy. Lancet, 366(9487), 726–732. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67177-2

items.description: Review of four randomized, placebo-controlled trials of homeopathy for migraine prophylaxis found variable trial quality; one small study reported benefit but the three methodologically stronger trials showed no effect beyond placebo, leading to the conclusion that homeopathy does not prevent migraine.
items.source_name: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
items.citation_apa: Ernst, E. (1999). Homeopathic prophylaxis of headaches and migraine? A systematic review. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management, 18(5), 353–357. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0885-3924(99)00095-0

items.description: Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of individualised homeopathic treatment in 68 migraine patients showed no significant difference in patient-recorded outcomes, but neurologist evaluation found a statistically significant reduction in attack frequency in the homeopathy group (P=0.04), suggesting possible partial efficacy.
items.citation_apa: Straumsheim, P., Borchgrevink, C., Mowinckel, P., Kierulf, H., & Hafslund, O. (2000). Homeopathic treatment of migraine: A double blind, placebo controlled trial of 68 patients. British Homœopathic Journal, 89(1), 4–7. https://doi.org/10.1054/homp.1999.0332

items.description: Rapid response commentary in BMJ noted that, had it been considered, the recent high-quality systematic review (Mathie et al. 2014) showing a significant difference favouring homeopathy would have classified homeopathic intervention as supported by good-quality evidence, indicating some specific effects beyond placebo.
items.citation_apa: BMJ Rapid Response. (2015). There is some evidence that individualised homeopathic intervention is more effective than placebo, report could have concluded. BMJ, 350, h1478. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.bmj.com/content/350/bmj.h1478/rr-13

items.description: Post-publication analysis of missing data from the Shang et al. 2005 Lancet meta-analysis showed that inclusion of omitted trials reverses the conclusion, indicating a significant effect of homeopathy beyond placebo when appropriate data are considered.
items.citation_apa: Linde, K., Jonas, W. B., & Lewith, G. (2008). The 2005 meta-analysis of homeopathy: the importance of post-publication data. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. https://doi.org/10.1016/S1475-4916(08)00089-1

items.description: A summary in American Family Physician (2006) reports that in high-quality trials, homeopathic therapies showed an odds ratio of 0.88 (95% CI, 0.65–1.19) versus placebo, while matched conventional therapy trials showed OR 0.58 (95% CI, 0.39–0.85), concluding homeopathy is no more effective than placebo (Level 1a– evidence).
items.citation_apa: American Family Physician. (2006). Homeopathy Is as Effective as Placebo. American Family Physician, 73(2), 312A. https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/2006/0115/p312a.html

items.description: An MDedge news article (2005) conveys the conclusion of European investigators led by Shang et al. that clinical effects reported for homeopathy are exclusively placebo and context effects, calling for abandonment of its scientific justification.
items.citation_apa: Walsh, N. (2005, October 15). Homeopathy Has Only Placebo and Context Effects, Study Says. Internal Medicine News. MDedge. https://www.mdedge.com/internalmedicinenews/article/12961/health-policy/homeopathy-has-only-placebo-and-context-effects

items.description: A Science in the net article (2017) summarises the European Academies’ Science Advisory Council (EASAC) position that no robust, reproducible evidence supports homeopathy’s effectiveness beyond placebo and highlights potential harms from delaying evidence-based care.
items.citation_apa: Redazione. (2017, September 21). Homeopathy: harmful or helpful? Science in the net. https://www.scienceonthenet.eu/articles/homeopathy-harmful-or-helpful/redazione/2017-09-21

items.description: The Commission on Pseudoscience (2017) memorandum “Homeopathy as Pseudoscience” states that homeopathy lacks scientific basis or evidence of effectiveness, contravenes established laws of chemistry and physics, and recommends withdrawal of homeopathic medicines from state clinics.
items.citation_apa: Commission on Pseudoscience. (2017). Homeopathy as Pseudoscience. In Commission on Pseudoscience Memoranda. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commission_on_Pseudoscience

items.description: The Live Science article reports that homeopaths invoke the “memory of water” hypothesis to explain how ultramolecular dilutions could retain therapeutic information despite containing no molecules of the original substance, suggesting an unforeseen mechanism beyond conventional chemistry.
items.citation_apa: Live Science. (2007). Homeopathy and the folly of watery memory. Live Science. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.livescience.com/1738-homeopathy-folly-watery-memory.html

items.description: The Faculty of Homeopathy’s Basic Science Research page summarizes physicochemical studies (thermoluminescence, Raman and UV–VIS spectroscopy, conductometry) showing that water dilutions prepared by homeopathic procedures display altered properties as a function of their history, supporting a water‐memory mechanism.
items.citation_apa: Faculty of Homeopathy. (n.d.). Basic science research. Faculty of Homeopathy. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://archive.facultyofhomeopathy.org/research/basic-science-research/

items.description: Nature News reports on Benveniste’s 1988 study showing that antibody‐containing solutions diluted beyond Avogadro’s limit still elicited basophil degranulation, prompting the suggestion that water could act as a “template” via hydrogen‐bonded networks or electromagnetic fields—an unexplained phenomenon.
items.citation_apa: Nature News. (2004, October 4). The memory of water. Nature. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.nature.com/news/2004/041004/full/news041004-19.html

items.description: A.V. Tschulakow et al. (2005) used a dinoflagellate bioassay to demonstrate that succussed water retains a measurable “memory” effect lasting at least ten minutes compared to unsuccussed controls, supporting an unforeseen mechanism based on soliton-like structures.
items.citation_apa: Tschulakow, A. V., Yan, Y., & Klimek, W. (2005). A new approach to the memory of water. Homeopathy, 94(4), 241–247. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.homp.2005.07.003

items.description: Del Giudice et al. (2007) employed flux calorimetry, conductometry, pHmetry, and galvanic‐cell electrode potential to show that homeopathic dilutions exhibit distinct physicochemical signatures, providing robust experimental support for water‐memory effects beyond standard solvent behavior.
items.citation_apa: Del Giudice, E., Preparata, G., Tedeschi, A., & Vitiello, G. (2007). The ‘Memory of Water’: an almost deciphered enigma. Homeopathy, 96(3), 163–169. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.homp.2007.05.007

items.description: An opinion piece in Chemistry World critiques quantum‐coherence–based explanations (Preparata and Del Giudice’s coherent domains) for water memory, noting that such domains have never been observed and the theory lacks empirical support, highlighting the speculative nature of water‐memory hypotheses.
items.citation_apa: Chemistry World. (n.d.). Homeopathy’s watered-down memory. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.chemistryworld.com/opinion/homeopathys-watered-down-memory/3005060.article

items.description: Montagnier et al. (2009) reported that aqueous nanostructures derived from bacterial DNA sequences emit low‐frequency electromagnetic signals at dilutions up to 10⁻¹², suggesting formation of stable water structures capable of carrying genetic information—an unforeseen biophysical mechanism.
items.citation_apa: Montagnier, L., Aïssa, J., Ferris, S., Montagnier, J.-L., & Lavallée, C. (2009). Electromagnetic signals are produced by aqueous nanostructures derived from bacterial DNA sequences. Interdisciplinary Sciences: Computational Life Sciences, 1(1), 81–90. https://doi.org/10.1007/s12539-009-0019-9

items.description: The Wikipedia entry on ‘Evidence and efficacy of homeopathy’ states that no physico‐chemical evidence supports stable water clusters or memory beyond picosecond timescales and that NMR studies found no differences between ultra‐dilutions and pure solvent.
items.citation_apa: Evidence and efficacy of homeopathy. (n.d.). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidence_and_efficacy_of_homeopathy

items.description: The Davidson Institute article argues that short‐lived hydrogen‐bond networks in liquid water (order of picoseconds) preclude any long‐term memory, making the water‐memory hypothesis implausible and supporting a no‐effect‐beyond‐placebo explanation.
items.citation_apa: Davidson Institute of Science Education. (201?) The ‘Memory of Water’: between science and homeopathy. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://davidson.org.il/read-experience/en/maagarmada-en/memory-water-between-science-and-homeopathy/

items.description: A systematic review and meta-analysis of 32 randomized, placebo-controlled trials of individualized homeopathic treatment across 24 conditions found a pooled odds ratio (OR) of 1.53 (95% CI 1.22–1.91) favoring homeopathy over placebo. A sensitivity analysis of three trials judged as “reliable evidence” showed OR = 1.98 (95% CI 1.16–3.38), indicating small but specific therapeutic effects of individually prescribed homeopathic medicines.
items.citation_apa: Mathie, R. T., Lloyd, S. M., Legg, L. A., Clausen, J., Moss, S., Davidson, J. R. T., & Ford, I. (2014). Randomised placebo-controlled trials of individualised homeopathic treatment: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Systematic Reviews, 3, 142. https://doi.org/10.1186/2046-4053-3-142

items.description: Meta-analysis of three double-blind, randomized clinical trials involving 242 children (ages 6 months to 5 years) with acute diarrhea showed that individualized homeopathic treatment reduced the duration of diarrhea to 3.3 days versus 4.1 days in placebo (P = 0.008), with an effect-size difference of approximately 0.66 days.
items.citation_apa: Jacobs, J., Jonas, W. B., Jiménez-Pérez, M., & Crothers, D. (2003). Homeopathy for childhood diarrhea: Combined results and meta-analysis from three randomized, controlled clinical trials. Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal, 22(3), 229–234. https://doi.org/10.1097/01.inf.0000055096.25724.48

items.description: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 144 patients with seasonal hay fever compared a homeopathic pollen potency to placebo. Homeopathy significantly reduced patient- and doctor-assessed symptom scores, halved antihistamine use, and showed initial aggravations followed by symptom improvement, indicating effects beyond placebo.
items.citation_apa: Reilly, D. T., Taylor, M. A., McSharry, C., & Aitchison, T. C. (1986). Is homoeopathy a placebo response? Controlled trial of homoeopathic potency, with pollen in hayfever as model. Lancet, 2(8512), 881–886. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(86)90410-1

items.description: A multicenter RCT with 51 patients having perennial allergic rhinitis found that a 30c homeopathic immunotherapy improved nasal inspiratory peak flow by a mean of 19.8 L/min compared to placebo (95% CI 10.4–29.1, P=0.0001). Pooled analysis of four trials showed a mean symptom reduction of 28% vs 3% for placebo (P=0.0007), reinforcing a specific effect of homeopathic dilutions.
items.citation_apa: Taylor, M. A., Reilly, D., Llewellyn-Jones, R. H., McSharry, C., & Aitchison, T. C. (2000). Randomised controlled trial of homoeopathy versus placebo in perennial allergic rhinitis with overview of four trial series. BMJ, 321(7259), 471–476. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.321.7259.471

items.description: Systematic review of 11 RCTs up to December 2015 on homeopathic treatments for seasonal or perennial allergic rhinitis. Meta-analysis of three Galphimia glauca trials (variable quality) showed nasal symptom relief risk ratios of 1.48 (95% CI 1.24–1.77) at 2 weeks and 1.27 (95% CI 1.10–1.46) at 4 weeks, and ocular symptom relief RR 1.55 (95% CI 1.33–1.80) and 1.37 (95% CI 1.21–1.56) favoring homeopathy.
items.source_name: Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine
items.citation_apa: Banerjee, K., Mathie, R. T., Costelloe, C., & Howick, J. (2017). Homeopathy for allergic rhinitis: A systematic review. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine, 23(6), 426–444. https://doi.org/10.1089/acm.2016.0310

items.description: In a double-blind RCT of 170 elderly patients (ages 60–80) with atherosclerosis-related vertigo, the homeopathic complex Vertigoheel improved dizziness questionnaire scores by 10.6 points versus 10.7 for Ginkgo biloba. Non-inferiority analysis showed Vertigoheel not inferior to G. biloba, with both treatments well tolerated.
items.source_name: Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine
items.citation_apa: Issing, W., Klein, P., & Weiser, M. (2005). The homeopathic preparation Vertigoheel versus Ginkgo biloba in the treatment of vertigo in an elderly population: A double-blinded, randomized, controlled clinical trial. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine, 11(1), 155–160. https://doi.org/10.1089/acm.2005.11.155

items.description: A double-blind, randomized non-inferiority trial comparing individualized homeopathic Q-potencies to fluoxetine (20–40 mg/day) over 8 weeks in 91 outpatients with moderate to severe depression found no significant differences in MADRS score changes at weeks 4 (P=0.654) and 8 (P=0.965). Non-inferiority margin of 1.45 was met; response and remission rates and tolerability were similar between groups.
items.citation_apa: Adler, U. C., Paiva, N. M. P., Cesar, A. T., Adler, M. S., Molina, A., Padula, A. E., & Calil, H. M. (2011). Homeopathic individualized Q‐potencies versus fluoxetine for moderate to severe depression: Double‐blind, randomized non‐inferiority trial. Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine, 2011, 520182. https://doi.org/10.1093/ecam/nep114

items.description: The UK House of Commons Science and Technology Committee’s 2010 report ‘Evidence Check 2: Homeopathy’ concluded that systematic reviews and meta-analyses demonstrate homeopathic products perform no better than placebos, and recommended withdrawal of NHS funding and MHRA licensing for homeopathic treatments.
items.citation_apa: Science and Technology Committee. (2010, February 22). Evidence Check 2: Homeopathy (Fourth Report of Session 2009-10, HC 45). UK Parliament.

items.description: A 2010 systematic review published in the Medical Journal of Australia concluded that findings of Cochrane reviews do not demonstrate that homeopathic medicines have effects beyond placebo across conditions such as cancer, ADHD, asthma, dementia, and influenza.
items.citation_apa: Ernst, E. (2010). Homeopathy: What does the “best” evidence tell us? Medical Journal of Australia, 193(3), 191–192.

items.description: A 2017 memorandum from the Commission to Combat Pseudoscience of the Russian Academy of Sciences declared homeopathy pseudoscientific, stating that ultra-low doses used in homeopathy have no scientific basis, contradict known laws of chemistry, physics, and biology, and that use of homeopathy can lead to harm or death by diverting patients from effective treatments.
items.citation_apa: The Independent. (2017). Russian Academy of Sciences says homeopathy is dangerous 'pseudoscience' that does not work. The Independent.

items.description: In a double-blind, randomized, five-armed trial with 83 rheumatoid arthritis patients, a homeopathic consultation (independent of remedy type) yielded clinically relevant improvements: DAS-28 mean difference 0.623 (95% CI 0.186–1.060; P=0.005; ES=0.70), swollen joint count mean difference 3.04 (95% CI 1.055–5.030; P=0.003; ES=0.83), current pain mean difference 9.12 (95% CI 0.521–17.718; P=0.038; ES=0.48), weekly pain mean difference 6.02 (95% CI 0.140–11.894; P=0.045; ES=0.30), and negative mood mean difference –4.50 (95% CI –8.071– –0.923; P=0.015; ES=0.90); no significant effects were observed for homeopathic remedies.
items.citation_apa: Brien, S., Lachance, L., Prescott, P., McDermott, C., & Lewith, G. (2011). Homeopathy has clinical benefits in rheumatoid arthritis patients that are attributable to the consultation process but not the homeopathic remedy: A randomized controlled clinical trial. Rheumatology (Oxford), 50(6), 1070–1082. doi:10.1093/rheumatology/keq234

items.description: In a randomized parallel-group trial with 208 children under 10 years old, mean URTI scores over 12 weeks were 39.0 in the homeopathic care group (individualized consultations plus any potency) and 43.9 in the self-prescribed medicine group (p=0.782; difference –5.0 points; 95% CI –20.5 to 10.5), with days rated ill 10.0 vs 13.7 (p=0.394), indicating no significant contextual benefit from the homeopathic consultation.
items.citation_apa: Steinsbekk, A., Lewith, G., Fønnebø, V., & Bentzen, N. (2007). An exploratory study of the contextual effect of homeopathic care: A randomized controlled trial of homeopathic care vs. self-prescribed homeopathic medicine in the prevention of upper respiratory tract infections in children. Preventive Medicine, 45(4), 274–279. doi:10.1016/j.ypmed.2007.02.004

items.description: A qualitative case series based on 18 patients at Bristol Homeopathic Hospital identified non-specific active ingredients in homeopathic care: patients’ openness to mind–body connection, consultational empathy, in-depth inquiry into bodily complaints, and disclosure, alongside the remedy-matching process, indicating that non-specific consultation factors contribute substantially to perceived therapeutic benefit.
items.citation_apa: Thompson, T. D. B., & Weiss, M. (2006). Homeopathy—what are the active ingredients? An exploratory study using the UK Medical Research Council’s framework for the evaluation of complex interventions. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine, 6, 37. doi:10.1186/1472-6882-6-37

items.description: A systematic literature review of placebo and nocebo effects in homeopathy using Medline found that expectations and unconscious conditioning elicit significant non-specific therapeutic effects measurable by imaging and EEG, which can obscure evaluation of any specific remedy effects and hamper selection of a simillimum.
items.citation_apa: Teixeira, M. Z., Guedes, C. H. F. F., Barreto, P. V., & Martins, M. A. (2010). The placebo effect and homeopathy. Homeopathy, 99(2), 119–129. doi:10.1016/j.homp.2010.02.001

items.description: An editorial highlights that trials demonstrate homeopathic remedies are inert, and that observed patient improvements are attributable to the consultation process rather than any specific remedy action.
items.citation_apa: Ernst, E. (2011). Homeopathy, non-specific effects and good medicine. Rheumatology (Oxford), 50(6), 1007–1008. doi:10.1093/rheumatology/keq265

items.description: A UK Science and Technology Committee report cites the Lancet systematic review by Di Blasi et al. (2001) showing that cognitive (expectation) and emotional (warm, empathic) care in trials significantly influenced health outcomes, underscoring the therapeutic impact of patient–practitioner context effects.
items.source_name: House of Commons Science and Technology Committee
items.citation_apa: Science and Technology Committee. (2009). Evidence Check 2: Homeopathy. House of Commons. Retrieved from https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmsctech/45/4504.htm

items.description: A systematic review covering 25 RCTs found that cognitive care (influencing expectations) and combined cognitive–emotional care (warm, reassuring consultations) significantly improved patient health outcomes, demonstrating the potency of context effects in therapeutic interventions.
items.citation_apa: Di Blasi, Z., Harkness, E., Ernst, E., Georgiou, A., & Kleijnen, J. (2001). Influence of context effects on health outcomes: A systematic review. Lancet, 357(9258), 757–762. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(00)04169-6

items.description: Basic Science Research on Homeopathy reports that low doses of nanoparticles from various source materials can initiate adaptive hormetic responses in living cells, and proposes that homeopathic dilutions deliver a low-intensity hormetic signal through mechanisms such as stochastic resonance, time-dependent sensitization, and hormesis
items.source_name: The American Association for Homeopathic Products
items.citation_apa: American Association for Homeopathic Products. (n.d.). Basic Science Research on Homeopathy. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://theaahp.org/articles/basic-science-research-on-homeopathy/

items.description: Jargin (2015) argues that generalizations of hormesis to homeopathy are unfounded, asserting that hormesis applies only to factors present in the natural environment, and warns that low-dose impacts may carry higher risks in organ systems near failure, particularly in elderly patients
items.citation_apa: Jargin, S. V. (2015). Hormesis and homeopathy: The artificial twins. Journal of Intercultural Ethnopharmacology, 4(1), 74–77. https://doi.org/10.5455/jice.20140929114417

items.description: Calabrese and Jonas (2010) present experimental models demonstrating that below-toxic threshold doses—within a measurable hormetic range—can enhance adaptive biological responses (post-conditioning hormesis), suggesting a framework by which aspects of homeopathy might be integrated into biomedical practice
items.citation_apa: Calabrese, E. J., & Jonas, W. B. (2010). Homeopathy: clarifying its relationship to hormesis. Human & Experimental Toxicology, 29(7), 531–536. https://doi.org/10.1177/0960327110369857

items.description: Moffett (2010) contends that hormesis and homeopathy are conceptually unrelated: hormesis is grounded in empirical toxicological experiments with measurable end-points, whereas homeopathy relies on ultramolecular dilutions without empirical evidence, making the notion of a beneficial hormetic dose moot
items.citation_apa: Moffett, J. R. (2010). Miasmas, germs, homeopathy and hormesis: Commentary on the relationship between homeopathy and hormesis. Human & Experimental Toxicology, 29(7), 539–543. https://doi.org/10.1177/0960327110369855

items.description: Bellavite, Chirumbolo, and Marzotto (2010) note that hormesis exhibits rigorously reported biphasic dose-response relationships and propose that the well-established hormesis framework may illuminate mechanisms of action for homeopathic remedies at ultra-low doses
items.citation_apa: Bellavite, P., Chirumbolo, S., & Marzotto, M. (2010). Hormesis and its relationship with homeopathy. Human & Experimental Toxicology, 29(7), 573–579. https://doi.org/10.1177/0960327110369771

items.description: Fisher (2010) reviews 73% of experiments showing in vivo effects with ultramolecular dilutions (68% in high-quality studies) and reports physical–chemical evidence of stable supramolecular structures and gas nanobubbles, suggesting that homeopathic preparations may generalize hormesis effects and raising questions about hormetic dose thresholds
items.citation_apa: Fisher, P. (2010). Does homeopathy have anything to contribute to hormesis? Human & Experimental Toxicology, 29(7), 555–560. https://doi.org/10.1177/0960327110369776

clusters.description: Large meta-analyses, Cochrane/major governmental or academy statements, and mainstream summaries concluding homeopathy shows no reliable effect beyond placebo and/or lacks plausibility.

H0.justification: H0 is a catch-all and makes no specific prediction about whether broad skeptical reviews/policy statements will dominate; set to base rate by rule (LR=1). (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: If remedies have specific effects beyond placebo, widespread high-level conclusions of null efficacy are less expected (though not impossible via error/bias), so below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If remedies have no specific effect beyond placebo, high-level null meta-analytic and institutional conclusions are strongly expected, so above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: If effects exist only for some conditions, blanket conclusions of 'no good evidence for any condition' are less expected; some skeptical outputs still expected due to heterogeneity/low quality, but overall below base. (P(E|H3)<P(E)). (below)

H4.justification: If benefits are mainly due to consultation/ritual and remedies are inert, then placebo-controlled remedy evidence and resulting skeptical reviews are fairly expected; above base but typically not as extreme as pure H2 because H4 still allows real non-specific benefit outside blinded remedy comparisons. (P(E|H4)>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: If only some non-ultra-diluted preparations could have low-dose effects, broad homeopathy-as-usually-practiced would often fail in RCTs, yielding many skeptical reviews; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 makes no specific prediction; per rule set to base rate. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under a pro-homeopathy paradigm that expects systemic bias/selection against homeopathy, even if H1 is true one may still expect many high-level skeptical statements; slightly above base. (P(E|H1)≥P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, skeptical institutional output remains very likely; above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: If only some conditions respond, a pro paradigm may still expect institutions to generalize 'no effect' (bias/over-aggregation), making this evidence close to/slightly above base. (P(E|H3)≈/≥P(E)). (above)

H4.justification: K1 treats institutional skepticism as weakly diagnostic and H4 does not uniquely predict institutional narratives beyond general placebo framing; approximate base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: Even if low-dose effects exist only in some preparations, institutions may still be broadly skeptical; slightly above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base rate. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under a skeptical paradigm, if H1 were true we'd expect robust signals to survive quality filters more often; thus widespread null high-quality conclusions are very unlikely; far below base. (P(E|H1)<<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: Under a skeptical paradigm, if H2 is true we strongly expect dominant null results and skeptical consensus; well above base. (P(E|H2)>>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: Even with condition-specific effects, K2 expects at least some clear successes if real; blanket skeptical conclusions are less expected, so below base. (P(E|H3)<P(E)). (below)

H4.justification: If benefits are ritual/relationship-driven with inert remedies, K2 expects high-quality remedy trials to be null and institutions to conclude 'placebo'; above base. (P(E|H4)>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: If only low-dilution hormesis exists, typical ultra-dilution homeopathy should still fail most trials; K2 expects skepticism; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

clusters.cluster_name: Clinical evidence reporting benefit beyond placebo (meta-analyses & RCTs)
clusters.description: Meta-analyses and controlled trials reporting statistically significant benefit of homeopathic remedies beyond placebo in at least some settings/conditions (including individualized and specific-condition trials).

H0.justification: H0 makes no specific prediction about a cluster of positive-trial claims; set to base rate by rule. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: If homeopathy has specific effects, the literature containing multiple RCT/meta-analytic positive findings is more likely than base; above base. (P(E|H1)>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If homeopathy has no effect beyond placebo, a cluster dominated by positive controlled findings is less likely (would require bias/error); below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: If homeopathy works for some conditions only, seeing a subset of positive findings across heterogeneous conditions is expected; above base (but typically less than H1 because effects are not universal). (P(E|H3)>P(E)). (above)

H4.justification: If effects arise from consultation/ritual rather than remedies, blinded placebo-controlled remedy benefits are not expected; below base. (P(E|H4)<P(E)). (below)

H5.justification: If some preparations at lower dilutions can have low-dose effects, occasional positive RCTs could occur; only weakly above base because many included trials are not clearly low-dilution/hormetic. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base rate. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under a pro-homeopathy paradigm, if H1 is true positive RCT/meta-analytic findings are strongly expected and more likely to be detected/retained; well above base. (P(E|H1)>>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: Even if H2 is true, K1 expects publication/selection artifacts producing some positive trials; still below base but closer than K0. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: If only some conditions respond, K1 expects multiple positive findings in those areas; above base. (P(E|H3)>P(E)). (above)

H4.justification: If consultation is the driver, placebo-controlled remedy effects are still relatively unlikely; below base. (P(E|H4)<P(E)). (below)

H5.justification: K1 treats hormesis/nanoparticle possibilities as more plausible; thus positive trial evidence is more expected under H5; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base rate. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Even under skepticism, if H1 were true we would still expect some positive results; above base but not extreme because K2 expects replication/quality filters to eliminate many false positives. (P(E|H1)>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, a multi-item cluster of positive RCT/meta-analytic claims is unlikely under K2 (though not impossible via bias/noise); below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: If effects exist only for some conditions, some positive findings are expected; above base. (P(E|H3)>P(E)). (above)

H4.justification: If effects are ritual-only, blinded remedy benefits should be rare; below base. (P(E|H4)<<P(E)). (below)

H5.justification: K2 discounts hormesis/nanoparticle relevance to most homeopathy trials; positive clinical findings are not especially expected under H5 here; below base. (P(E|H5)<P(E)). (below)

clusters.description: Evidence that improvements correlate with consultation quality, expectation management, and therapeutic relationship, or that remedy-specific effects appear inert relative to context effects.

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive about whether consultation/context effects will be prominent; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: H1 does not specifically predict consultation/ritual effects being the primary driver (they can co-exist with specific remedy effects), so treat as non-predictive here; set to base. (P(E|H1)=P(E)). (equal)

H2.justification: If remedies are inert, non-specific placebo/context mechanisms are expected to explain perceived benefit; above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: H3 focuses on condition-specific remedy effects and does not uniquely predict consultation effects dominating; non-predictive for this cluster; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 directly predicts that consultation/relationship drives outcomes independent of remedy; strong match, above base. (P(E|H4)>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: H5 concerns low-dose biological effects and does not uniquely predict consultation-context findings; set to base. (P(E|H5)=P(E)). (equal)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under K1, if H1 is true, framing outcomes as primarily consultation-driven is somewhat less expected (though still possible), so below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: Even in K1, if H2 is true, consultation/context explanations are plausible and should appear; slightly above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: If only some conditions respond to remedies, K1 expects less emphasis on pure consultation explanations; slightly below base. (P(E|H3)<P(E)). (below)

H4.justification: If H4 is true, consultation/ritual evidence is expected, but K1 assumes these findings may be under-emphasized relative to remedy narratives; still above base. (P(E|H4)>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: If benefits are low-dose biological, consultation/ritual dominance is less central; below base. (P(E|H5)<P(E)). (below)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under K2, if H1 were true, we'd expect remedy-specific signals to dominate over consultation-only explanations more often; thus this cluster is below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If remedies are inert, K2 expects outcomes to be attributed to placebo/context and therapeutic interaction; above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: If only some conditions respond specifically, consultation effects may still exist but should not dominate; below base. (P(E|H3)<P(E)). (below)

H4.justification: H4 directly predicts this cluster and K2 expects it to be prominent; well above base. (P(E|H4)>>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: Low-dose hormesis does not predict consultation-driven effects; below base under K2. (P(E|H5)<P(E)). (below)

clusters.cluster_name: Mechanistic claims: water memory / physicochemical signatures / anomalous effects
clusters.description: Claims and studies suggesting ultradilutions/succussion leave measurable physicochemical signatures or biological effects, along with mechanistic discussion/critique around water-memory-like hypotheses.

H0.justification: H0 is a catch-all and does not specifically predict these particular mechanism-claim patterns; set to base by rule. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: If homeopathy has specific effects via unknown mechanisms, some reproducible physicochemical anomalies are more likely than base; above base. (P(E|H1)>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If there is no effect beyond placebo and no special mechanism, a cluster of mechanistic anomaly claims is less likely (though could occur via artifact/low-quality studies); below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 is about condition-specific clinical effects and does not specifically predict physicochemical-signature literature; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: If effects are purely ritual/context, mechanistic physicochemical signatures tied to remedies are not expected; below base. (P(E|H4)<P(E)). (below)

H5.justification: If low-dose/nanoparticle mechanisms are relevant, some measurable physicochemical differences could be expected; moderately above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under a pro paradigm, if H1 is true mechanistic anomalies are expected and taken as meaningful; well above base. (P(E|H1)>>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K1 still expects some anomaly-claim literature but less than if H1 were true; below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 does not specifically predict physicochemical signatures; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: If effects are ritual-only, remedy-linked physicochemical anomalies are less expected; below base. (P(E|H4)<P(E)). (below)

H5.justification: K1 treats nanoparticle/hormesis-style mechanisms as plausible, so physicochemical differences are more expected; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under K2, if H1 were true strong, reproducible mechanistic evidence would be expected more decisively; the observed mix of claims/criticisms is less expected; below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K2 still expects some mechanistic-claim literature to exist due to motivated reasoning/artefacts alongside critique; slightly above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: H3 is not specifically about physicochemical signatures; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: If effects are ritual/context, K2 expects proponents to generate mechanistic stories to justify remedies; slightly above base. (P(E|H4)>P(E)). (above)

H5.justification: K2 doubts hormesis/nanoparticle relevance at ultra-dilutions; thus this mechanistic-claim cluster is less expected as genuine signal under H5; below base. (P(E|H5)<P(E)). (below)

clusters.description: Evidence and commentary proposing (or criticizing) hormesis/nanoparticle mechanisms as a partial explanation for some homeopathic preparations, focusing on low-dose biological responses and conceptual fit.

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive about whether a hormesis/nanoparticle debate literature exists; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: If homeopathy works via an unknown remedy-specific mechanism (e.g., water memory), a distinct hormesis/nanoparticle debate is not especially expected; below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If no specific effect exists, some debate literature may still exist but sustained supportive low-dose mechanistic claims are less expected overall; below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 does not specifically predict hormesis/nanoparticle mechanistic debate; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 (ritual/context) does not specifically predict a low-dose mechanism debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: H5 directly predicts that low-dose/hormetic/nanoparticle mechanisms should be discussed and supported by some experimental models; above base. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: Under K1, mechanistic pluralism is encouraged; even if H1 is true, hormesis/nanoparticle frameworks are viewed as supportive adjuncts; slightly above base. (P(E|H1)>P(E)). (above)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K1 still expects some hormesis discussion but less than if H5 were true; below base. (P(E|H2)<P(E)). (below)

H3.justification: H3 is not specifically a hormesis hypothesis; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 does not specifically predict hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: K1 expects strong visibility of hormesis/nanoparticle evidence if H5 is true; well above base. (P(E|H5)>>P(E)). (above)

H0.justification: H0 is non-predictive; set to base. (P(E|H0)=P(E)). (equal)

H1.justification: K2 expects hormesis/nanoparticle debate to be a post-hoc rationalization rather than a core prediction of H1; below base. (P(E|H1)<P(E)). (below)

H2.justification: If H2 is true, K2 expects a mix of speculative supportive claims and critical rebuttals to exist; slightly above base. (P(E|H2)>P(E)). (above)

H3.justification: H3 is non-predictive about hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H3)=P(E)). (equal)

H4.justification: H4 is non-predictive about hormesis debate; set to base. (P(E|H4)=P(E)). (equal)

H5.justification: Even under K2, if H5 were true some hormesis/nanoparticle evidence/debate is expected; above base but not extreme due to skepticism about applicability to ultra-dilutions. (P(E|H5)>P(E)). (above)
